Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Story:
I stared at the calendar, my phone buzzing with reminders. My sister had just texted, “Don’t forget, we’re all meeting at Grandma’s for the holiday dinner at six. Mom says it’s really important this year.” I knew how much these family gatherings meant, especially since we hadn’t all been together in months. I could already picture my parents’ disappointed faces if I showed up late or missed it.

But as I was about to leave, I spotted my new neighbor, Mrs. Kim, struggling with her groceries. I’d baked a small cake to welcome her, hoping to make a good impression and start off on the right foot in this new place. She smiled when she saw me, clearly expecting a friendly chat and maybe a cup of tea together. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down on me—my family waiting, my neighbor hoping for kindness. My heart pounded as I stood there, cake in hand, torn between the warmth of home and the promise of new connections, unsure which door to walk through first.
